div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,458] ALEXANDRIA, MONDAY, APRIL 2, 1906. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth, and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is 22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST:

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Arden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MERSINE, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Badam and SUAKIN direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODEIDAB, ADEN. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Milan, Loverne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi at 7 a.m. Arrival Venice every Wednesday about 8.30 a.m. in time fro Express to Switzerland, Paris, and London, leaving Venice 2 p.m. and 11.20 p.m. Arrival Trieste every Wednesday about 3 p.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carriages and luggage-van attached every Saturday to Express leaving Cairo 9.30 a.m. and are conveyed directly to Quay alongside steamer. (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.

Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.

div.head: MONDAY, APRIL 2, 1906.
ALGECIRAS.
div.p: The whole civilised world will welcome the news of the happy issue of the most momentous international debate that has been convened since the Berlin Conference. A few days ago, in discussing the possible peaceful termina¬tion of the Algeciras conference, the “Morning Post” declared that it would have been a mis-fortune of the first magnitude if the affair of Morocco had led to a quarrel between any of the Great Powers. In spite of the strong na¬tional feeling which exists in each of the coun- tries principally concerned in these negotiations there is no sane and sensible man either in Germany, France, Spain, or Great Britain who really thinks that Morocco, taken on the maximum valuation, is worth a conflict be¬tween any of the Powers. Supposing its soil to be the most fertile, its climate the most bene- ficent in the world, and its mineral wealth to be inexhaustible, yet the question whether the task of bringing into its administration the beginnings of order and of giving to European residents and traders the elements of security for person and property should be

entrusted to one Power or to more, and even the question whether a settlement now made might or might not give one Power something of a special position in the country, are not worth a struggle between civilised Powers. Such a conflict would in six months destroy more wealth and absorb more human energy than Morocco could in any case reproduce in half a century, Of this all the Powers concern¬ed are firmly convinced, and the fact that they are so having been well known has made graver, from the beginning, the anxiety with which the possibility of a deadlock has been regarded. Everyone has put the question, “What’s he to Hecuba or Hecuba to him ?” and in the absence of a possible answer has sought behind the friction and delay which have attended upon diplomacy for sums profound explanation. The great prestige with which Bismarck sur-rounded the policy of the German Empire, the presumed astuteness and profundity of German diplomacy, and the generally recognised excel¬lence of the German military and naval organi¬sation have erased most observers to imagine that Germany had some deep design. The theory weir known to be held by many officers of the German Army that Germany ought to take the first opportunity to attack France in order that she might be unable to take part in the future conflict which, these same officers imagine to be inevitable between Germany and Great Britain, lent itself to the hypothesis that the German Government was meditating an attack upon France of which the excuse was to be found in some disagreement con- cerning Morocco. The tone in which the German Government has for several years without a solitary exception alluded to its relations with Great Britain has lent colour to the same hypothesis. Even when a British Ad¬miral on a visit to a German port in the Baltic sent a message conveying his respects to the German Emperor, the Emperor’s reply was almost as frigid and as chilling to British feelings as his famous message to President Kruger. Sentiment asked what these things meant, and could only infer that they boded no good. But the German Emperor, though he is a careful student of German sentiment, and therefore as a rule carries it with him even when—perhaps especially when—he offends the sentiment of other nations, is not a senti¬mental statesman. He is always doing business, and the feelings of his own and other rations are a portion of the data upon which his calculations are based. He has not, and never has had, the idea of plunging Germany into an international conflict without knowing the reason why and without foreseeing a satis ¬-factory ending. In the case which has been during the last few months thought possible, there has been no sufficient reason why. Ger¬many was subject to no menace. Her territory, her rights, her interests were in no way threat -ened. It is just conceivable that Prince Bulow may have taken umbrage at the expression used in the Anglo-French Agreement about Morocco by which Great Britain ‘ recognised that France was entitled to a peculiar posit on in that country. But though the words used may not have been formally unexceptionable, and would, perhaps, have been better omitted, seeing that the substance was perfect¬ly conveyed by the undertaking not to obstruct the action which France might take in Morocco any objection that could be raised was merely formal, fir no one in the world doubted that Morocco and its good order was a matter of special interest to France, and no one in the world supposed that Great Britain claimed any right to dispose of anything in Morocco beyond her own rights and interests in that country.The probability is that the German Govern¬ment wished it to be understood that no such settlement as that of the future of Morocco ought to be effected without Germany’s being con¬sulted and being a consenting party. That having been made plain, and that wish having been met, the main intention of German policy in the matter has probably been fulfilled. No doubt there may be a little more behind. Bismarck and his disciples learned something from Napoleon, and Napoleon learned from his master in strategy never to make a project without two faces. It is likely enough, there- fore, that Germany, while pressing her point in regard to Morocco, has had her eye on something else as well, and that while the theory of the right of Germany to be consulted in any settlement of Morocco has been asserted the wishes of Germany in regard to the Middle East have also been kept in mind. That remains to be seen.

div.head: Local and General
div.p: Yachts.
The British S. Y. Evona arrived at Alex¬-andria on Saturday from Bombay and Pet Said, and the Honor from Messina yesterday.
Hashish Seizure.
On Saturday the Coastguards seized 15 kilos of hashish by the shore near Agame. It had evidently been thrown overboard the night before by some boat whioh was unable to land it.
Lots Turcs.
We are informed by the Imperial Ottoman Bank and the Credit Lyonnais that the gros lot of the Ottoman Railway Lottery was won on Saturday by the holder of bond No. 1,544,100.
Pyramid Illuminated.

On the occassion of the visit of the Prince end Princess of Wales to the Pyramids on Wednesday, the Pyramid of Cheops will be illuminated and the management of Mena House Hotel has prepared special dinners for those who are going out that night.
Finds at Oxyrhynchus.

The work of discovery at Oxyrhynchus during the last season has resulted in a large accumulation of material, no fewer than one hundred and seventeen boxes of papyri being brought away. Among the most interesting finds are a comedy of Philemon on which Plautus based his “Aulularia,” and a discourse on music, perhaps by Hippias of Elis. A con-¬tract dated in the fifth year of Sotu I. furnishes the oldest date yet found on a Geek papyrus. A very interesting document is a Greco- Roman calendar about BC 300, giving data as to the various deities and their festivals.
Researchers in Sinai.

The materials and discussions of Professor Flinders Petrie’s new book, ‘Researches in Sinai," which will shortly be published, are not drawn from any previous publication. They contain the first detailed account of the Egyptian remains in Sinai, the results being given in chronology, with a revision of the dates in Egyptian history according to the most recent results. The Semitic discoveries, which are entirely new, include the system of Semitic ritual and the common use of a Semitic writing in the earliest age, the conditions of climate, the route of the Exodus, the question of the numbers of the Israelites down to the monarchy, and the evidences of early docu¬ments in the Pentateuch.
Spend your Holidays at Mena,
The management of Mena House Hotel has arranged special terms for residents of Cairo, Alexandria, and country from the 10th of April to the 10th of May. [Advt.]

div.head: Egyptian Estates
div.p: Report of Directors

The following is the report of the directors of the Egyptian Estates, to be submitted to the shareholders at the first annual general meeting to be held at Winchester House. Old Broad, street, London, E C., on Wednesday, 11th inst. : — The directors herewith present the first balance sheet and profit and loss account made up to the 13th March, 1906. The company was registered on the 3rd March, 1905, but it was some months before it was able to commence operations, and the average period for which the subscribed capital has been available does not exceed six months. During the past three months 179.315 additional ordinary shares have been issued, of which 153,315 will row rank for dividend with the original capital. Five per cent, debentures have also been issued for £150 000 part of £300 0 0 created. If the issue of the remainder should be thought advisable, the available resources of the company, include-ing the reserves now created, would amount to over £800,000. The whole of the lands and properties shown in the balance sheet are car¬r-ied at cost, and on a revaluation would shows a large appreciation on the purchase price. The amount to the credit of profit and loss account is £67.177 1649d. This does not include a sum of £25,655 17s. 7d. shown in the balance sheet, but which, although ascertained profit, is only payable by instalments extending over the next 2 1/2 years, and is, therefore, not divisible profit at the present time. The directors pro-pose the payment of a dividend of 2s. per share, free of income tax upon the ordinary shares. This will absorb £40,492 2s, and will entail an appropriation of £ 0,900 to the deferred shares, which will admit of a dividend of 10s. 9d. per share being paid on these shares. The directors, in the exercise of their powers, have placed £126 071 17s. 6d. to reserve, being the amount of premiums received on shares allotted since the issue of the prospectus, against which have been written oft the whole of the preliminary expenses an 1 the expenses of the debenture issue to date, leaving a ret balance on reserve account of £10-1,090 12s. l0d. In accordance with Article 99 of the Articles of Association, the Directors are entitled to one- tenth of the profits over and above an amount sufficient to pay a dividend of 7 per cent. per annum on the ordinary shares, and £3,23 5s. 4d. will be appropriated under this head. These various amounts, deducted from the £67 177 16s. 9d. will, after due provision has been made for income tax, leave a balance of £9/89 Us. 7d. The directors wish to place upon record their high appreciation of the services rendered to the company by the managing director in Egypt, Mr. Montagu Summers, and of the able co-operation of Mr. Lang Anderson and George Nungovich Bey.

div.head: The Austrian Squadron
div.p: The Austro-Hungarian colony at Alexandria gave a magnificent fete yesterday afternoon in honour of Rear-Admiral von Jedina and the officers of the Imperial and Royal squadron now at Alexandria. The fete took place at the New Khedivial Hotel from 4 to 8 o’clock and was attended by all the leading representatives of Alexandrian society, the officers of the Ame¬rican man-of war Brooklyn, the members of the Diplomatic and Consular Corps, etc. This evening there will be a fete at the A’hambra Theatre in honour of the petty officers and sailors of the squadron On Thursday next Rear Admiral von Jedina and the officers will give a ball on board the Habsburg and the St. George.
Anglo-American Nile Steamer & Hotel Company
River Transport of Good Between Alexandria & Cairo
Three Sailings a-Week.

Alexandria Bonded Warehouse Co. Ld

div.head: The Royal Visit
div.p: T.R.H. at All Saints'
VISIT PAID TO THE BARRAGE

Yesterday their Royal Highnesses the Prince and Princess of Wales attended morning service at All Saints’ Church Cairo. Of coarse, the building was crowded and it was fortunate that the restoration of the north aisle had been completed or there would not have been room for the congregation. As it is, the in¬adequacy of the church accommodation is only too apparent. Three clergymen took part in the service. Rev. Thompson Barns, M. A., read the prayers, Right Rev. Bishop Morley, D.D., acting Archdeacon in Egypt, celebrated the Holy Communion, and the Very Rev. Dean Butcher preached from the 1st Lesson Exodus 8.2: ‘‘And he looked, and behold the bush burned with fire and the bush was not consumed." The Dean spoke of the scene of the vision of the Peninsula of Sinai, of which we now know much more than we ever did before, and of the symbolism of the vision itself, the fire representing, first, the discipline of trial, secondly, the comforting and enlightening effects of the Holy Spirit. He mentioned the fact that the burning bush and the text were the emblem and motto of the Church of Scot¬land. He quoted Matthew Arnold’s well-known sonnet on Marcus Aurelius: “ There were no suoccours here The aids to noble life were all within.” and contrasted this with the experience of the humblest Christian, who can always obtain through Christ—help from outside— the aid of the Holy Spirit. The hymns selected by their Royal High¬nesses were No. 260 in H A. and M., “Hark my soul," No. 438 ‘ How bright those glorious spirits shine," and 215, ‘ The Church’s one Foundation." There was an unusually large choir admirably directed by Mr. Peacock. The Earl of Cromer met the Royal party at the church door and sat with them in the Agency pew. General Bullock, C.B., Major Watson Pacha, C.M.G., D.S.O., and several members of the suite occupied the first four seats. After attending divine service their Royal Highnesses returned to Abdeen Palace, after¬wards lunching with Brig. General Bullock. In the afternoon they paid a visit to the Barrage, accompanied by H.H. the Khedive, by whose desire the gardens were closed to the public during the afternoon. Sir Wm. Garstin also accompanied their Royal High¬nesses. The party went out on the Khedive's yacht. The Nile was so rough and the wind so trying, however, that the Khedive and T. R. H., after arriving at the Barrage and inspecting the works, gardens, etc., wired to Cairo for a special train, by which the re¬turn journey was made.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: Six cases of plague were reported from the Keneh district on Saturday, four of them terminating fatally. The Public Health Department has just issued a report on bubonic plague in Egypt from February 26 to April 1, which shows a total of 19 oases, 15 of which have proved fatal, the remainder being under treatment.

div.head: H.M.S. Perseus
div.p: Commander Marcus Rowley Hill, R.N., of H.M S. Perseus, was introduced on an official visit to Ibrahim Halim Bey, the Governor of Suez, by Mr. V. Hughes-Laferla, British Pro-Consul at Suez, on Saturday last. The Governor returned the visit on board the Perseus the same afternoon. H.M.S. Perseus is a 3rd-class twin-screw cruiser. She is returning to her station at Aden to-day.

div.head: A GALLANT RESCUE.
div.p: Yesterday morning, at about 10.30 o’clock, a Greek was walking along the lower parapet of the new quay near Fort Silsileh, when he slipped and fell into the sea. The nearest Coast- guard sentry was informed and he promptly proceeded to the spot with a life-saving apparatus. By this time the Greek had drifted oat about sixty yards from the quay wall and was too exhausted to swim to the buoy, which had been thrown out as far as possible. The sea was breaking heavily over the wall and there appeared to be little hope for the man, as although there was a small crowd of onlookers no one proffered any help. However, a Coast¬guard orderly, Ahmed Ibrahim Hamid, who was passing by, on seeing the man’s predica¬ment, called to the crowd and asked whether any of them would try to save the life of the drowning man. No one made reply, so he at once stripped and plunged into the sea. He swam out with the buoy to the Greek and assisted him alongside the quay, where he was hauled up. If this act of bravery had taken place at home the rescuer would certainly have been entitled to the medal of the Royal Humane Society. There are decorations, Medjidish and Osmanieh, for the officers, but there is none for the men in Egypt. Why should not a special Order be created for deeds of bravery? At any rate it is to be hoped that the brave coastguardeman will meet with some reward.

div.head: MILITARY TOURNAMENT
div.p: GREAT SOCIAL SUCCESS.
PRESENCE OF ROYALTY.

This year’s Military Tournament at Abbas- sieh was honoured by the presence of the Prince and Princess of Wales, and in consequence of this fact, and of the excellent management of the committee, proved a great social success. It was from every point of view a social event of the first magnitude, and we have never seen so representative a gathering so late in the Cairo season. The committee had done their work admirably throughout. The eighteen events on their programme were all attractive and often amusing. The tent pegging was de- cidedly good, the riders taking the pegs with great finish and neatness. The wrestling on horseback delighted the audience—though for other reasons than the tent pegging—and the physical drill displays, bayonet fighting and contests between various aims delighted all who watched them. But it was the social and not the athletic side of the function that made it most interesting to all who were present. Here again, the committee, after issuing a great number of invitations, had obviously made up its mind to do all in its power for the entertainment of its guests. The enclosure was therefore roped in on the S. E. side of the parade ground so that neither sun nor wind made their presence unduly felt—a boon and blessing if ever was one. A smaller en¬closure was reserved for the Ministers, the Diplomatic and Consular Corps, and for the members of the Caisse de la Dette, and next to it was the Khedivial tent. At the opposite extremity of the enclosure was the tea tent, which was always thronged and admirably managed by Mr. Wild of the Savoy Hotel. George Nungovich Bey devoted himself with skill and assiduity to the supply of the Khe-divial party and the Royal visitors. The fact that in spite of the presence of nearly 1,000 visitors the tea tent triumphantly met all demands (on a warm afternoon too) merits mention. The committee, which deserves any amount of credit for its successful organisation of the tournament, and of thanks for the hospitality extended to so many guests by its members in conjunction with the Sirdar and the officers corps of the Egyptian Army, consisted of, Miralai Matehett Bey, Miralai Palmer Bey, Kaimakam Gordon Bey, Kaimakam Stockwell Bey Kaimakam Hassan Bey Hilmy, Bimbashi Flint. Bimbasbi Betbell, Bimbashi Broadbent and Bimbashi Rome. The programme had been drawn up by Saghcologassi Ahmed Effendi Fetin. The police arrangements and traffic control were perfect and Man-field Pacha’s subordinates did wonders. The native population of Cairo was there is its thousands. A long row of harem carriages on the side of the parade-ground opposite to the enclosure testified to the interest aroused among the Turkish and Arab ladies of Cairo by the tournament and the Royal visit, and the rank and file of the Egyptian Army were out in hundreds. The Corps Diplomatique, the Ministers, and the members of the Legislative Council were present in full strength at the ceremony. The Sirdar and Lady Wingate with a strong con¬tingent of officers and officials from the Sudan were present, and among others we noticed Sir William Garstin, Lord Edward Cecil, Mr. Percy Macbell and Lady Victoria Machell. Mr. and Mrs. And Mrs. De C. Findlay, Sir John and Lady Rogers, Sir Horace Pinching, Mr. Douglas Dunlop, Mr. Dugdale and the Lady Eva Dugdale, Crookshank Pacha and Mrs. Crook shank, Mr. Webb, Sir Augustus and Lady Hemming, Miss Hemming, Gen. Bullock, Mrs. Bullock, Miss Bullock, Coles Pacha, Mrs. Coles and the Misses Coles, Mr. and Mrs. Scott Dalgleish Mr. and Mrs. Alban, the Misses Hurley, Mr. and Mrs, Rumboldt, Mr. Higgins, Mr. and Mrs. George Royle, Major Stack, Judge and Mrs. Marshall, Owen Bey, Capt. and Mrs. Failey, Mr. and Mrs. Allan Joseph, Miss Joseph, Mr. Dicey, Mr. and Mrs. Autley Friend, Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Perry, Mr. Stout, Mrs. and Miss Reid, Mr. D. Reid, Mr. J Reid, Mr. Berens, Mr. and Mrs. Huteson, Mrs. Wallich, Mr. and Miss de Bilinski, Major and Mrs. Donegan, Capt. and Mrs. Morgan, Mr. and Miss Farrell, Miss Alicia Brown, Mrs. and the Misses York, Mrs. and Miss Leverich, Mrs. and Miss Whittaker, Mr. and Mrs. Wild, Mr. and Mrs. Tatton Brown, Major and Mrs. Wynne, Mrs. and Miss Rees, Miss de Codt, Mr. and Mrs. Hogg, Mrs. Parvis, Milhem Bey Shakoor and Miss Shakoor, Judge and Mrs. Tuck, Dr. and Mrs. Phillips, Dr and Mrs. Nolan, Mr. Hayter. Mrs. Rom, Miss Phillips, Capt. and Mrs. Duffus, Miss Langley, Dr. and Mrs. Madden, Dr. and Mrs. Milton, Mr. Potts, Mr. and Mrs. Wells, Mr. and Mrs. Satow, Mr. Roche, Mr. and Mrs. Hogg,—but the mere repetition of names, however pleasant their associations, must weary the reader and might be continued over columns. H.H. the Khedive arrived comparatively early at the tournament, followed shortly afterwards by H.RH. the Prince of Wales. H.RH. the Princess of Wales arrived later, after visiting H.H. the Khedivah and H.H. the Khedivah Mother at Koubbeh Palace in company with Lady Cromer, with whom she left Abdeen at 3.30 p.m. and proceeded by special train, leaving Pont Limoun station at 3.45 p.m. Lord Cromer arrived shortly after H.R.H the Princess of Wales had driven up. The Royal visitors were greatly pleased with all they saw of the tournament, and H.H. the Khedive was kind enough to express to the Sirdar his high appreciation of the arrange¬ments made. It was indeed one of the great events, perhaps the great event of the season.

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID
div.p: NEW HARBOUR WORKS.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
Port Said, Saturday.

The erection of warehouses in connection with the Menzaleh Canal is nearing completion. They are being built behind Dowrie’s point and will shortly be ready to receive cargo. The Custom House and railway lines have also been started and when finished should be of great benefit to the tradespeople of the town. Messrs. Wills and Sons’ engineers have now arrived and things will 60on be in fall swing in connection with the new harbour and docks which are being built on the N. E. shore of Port Said. All the stone for the construction of the harbour and docks are to come from Suez by barges, which I understand have al¬ready been despatched from England. Murder at Ras el Ech. Some little time ago a burglary was com¬mitted at Ras el Ech and two police officers were sent from Cairo to enquire into the matter. No arrests were made, but a number of Greeks were brought up for examination. These Greeks were examined one by one, and after answering some questions one of them pulled a revolver out of his pocket, and, before any one could realise the situation, shot one of the officers in the brain, killing him on the spot. The body of the unfortunate officer was taken to Cairo accompanied by a force of 200 police from the Capital. Hotel Improvements, Messrs. Wills and Co. are making some ex¬tensive alterations to the Eastern Exchange. The shop under the hotel is, I hear, to be transformed into tea-rooms. This should prove a successful innovation. Football. The football season at Port Said has come to an end, and I think the Port Said Club have had a record year for the number of games, if not wins. Rugby and hockey have taken the place of Association to a great extent, and the young sportsmen here must feel very thankful for the presence of a guardship here again as one can always get up a match of some sort.

div.head: THE BUDGET.
div.p: FIVE MILLIONS SURPLUS.
Our London Correspondent telegraphs to-day that the Budget surplus amounts to nearly five millions sterling.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MARKETS.
div.p: FRESH DEBENTURE ISSUE.

We understand that the Egyptian Markets Company have arranged for a further issue of 5% second Debentures with a view to the construction of slaughter-houses in various centres. The amount arranged for is (gap)5 000 the whole of which has been placed with Messrs. Reid and Barnard at par, less 2% commission.

div.head: CAIRO HOTEL COMBINE.
div.p: A big English company with a capital of £500.000 is negotiating for the purchase of the National and several other hotels in Egypt. The combination will include about seven hotels right up to Khartoum.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES.
div.p: A report has been current to the effect that the Hon. A. J. Davey was about to leave Egypt to avoid the institution of legal proceed¬ings against him. We understand that, in order to dispel any erroneous impressions of this nature. Mr. Davey has abandoned his intention of leaving Egypt for the present

div.head: APPOINTMENTS.
div.p: Mr. H. Bowden-Smith, secretary to the Financial Adviser, is about to be transferred to the Public Lands Department with the rank of inspector. He will be replaced at the Ministry of Finance by Mr. Etherington Smith, who will take over Mr. Bowden-Smith’s duties in the immediate future. May we wish that the new secretary may be "Felicitor Augusto, melior Trajano.”

div.head: HIKR RIGHTS ON LAND.
div.p: From day to day the rights of hike on land grow less and less in consequence of the deci¬sions of the Mixed Appeal Court and the Wakfs General Administration that the rights could be definitely bought off on payment of a lump sum equivalent to the dues for twenty years to come. The Wakfs, for the benefit of which these hikrs had been originally created, invest the money obtained for relinquishment of •he rights in land, which is turned into Wakfs, bringing in far more than the hikrs, which required a great deal of money and trouble to collect.

div.head: BAND PERFORMANCE.
div.p: By kind permission of Lt-Col. C. J. Mark- ham and officers, the band of the 1st King’s Royal Rifles will perform the following selec¬tion of music at the Ghezireh Gymkhana on Tuesday : -

March-Weddmere-Losey Overture in the Italian Style—Schubert. Intermezzo—Bal d'Enfante—Gascone. Selection—Carmen—Bizet. Russian Dance—Pas de Patineurs—Godfrey. Valse—La Gitana—Bucalossi. Selection—The Bohemians—Puccini. Galop March—Russe—Ganne. Regimental March—Khedivial Anthem.
God Save the King.
THOMAS BROWN, Bandmaster

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H.R H. the Prince of Wales received the President and members of the Legislative Council at Abdeen Palace at 2.30 p.m. yester¬day.
A Luxor Correspondent telegraphs that T.R.H. the Archduke Joseph and Archduchess Augusta of Austria and suite have arrived at Luxor from the Sudan and are staying at the Luxor Hotel.
Leave of absence, on private affairs, has been granted to Major C.LE. Robertson-Eustace, 1st King’s Royal Rifle Corps, to June 80.
Mr. Lang Anderson left this morning for London by the P and 0. S3. Osiris from Port Said.He expects to return to Alexandria on the 26th inst.

Among the latest arrivals at the Savoy I Hotel, Port Said, we notice the Marquise de I Clapiers, Commodore Tyrwiht, Capt. Sheppard, Lieut. Wilson, Capt. Moore, Mrs. Maclnnes, Mr. C. Crossland, Mrs. A. Low, Mr. Low, Col. and Mrs. Hill, Mr. Tebb Scott and party, Mr. S. Norton, Mr. and Mrs Soddlei, M. Siese, Miss Mihalek, M. and Mme de Lalan, Mr. and Mrs. Durand, Baron de Brenker, Mr. Roundel, Mr. and Mrs. Lyon, Mrs. Sexton. Mr. Fox. Mr. and Mrs. Hambrook, Mr. Frank Hovill, Mr. Chal- mers Bontein, Mr. Wills.
The Vaccari family beg to thank their friends for the many tokens of kind sympathy they have received on the death of Mr Arbo- gasto Vaccari. of Alexandria, and also those who attended the funeral.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd’ hui d midi et demie)

11 y a eu oe matin on re'evement sensible a la suite des bonnes nonvelles venues d’Alge-siras. Les titres les plusen faveur sont l’Agricole qui s’avance a 10 3/16. l’lnvestment a 1 17/32 H la Comptoir a 7 9/16 et la Land Bank a 9 H 1/16 1’anoienne et 8 5/8 la nouvelle. On assure en bourse quo l’Egyptian Invest- ment and Agency est sur le point He lancer une banque de reports. Si la nouvelle se oonfir- me, nous verrons le cours cette valeur haus-se d’une facon considerable.

Il y a eu ausrs an petit mouvement en Natio¬nal Bank, Delta Land et Cassa Hi Sconto. La Ramleh Railway et la Delta Light sont momentanement delaissees a des cours avanta- geux. L’assemblee generale ordinaire de la Societe anonyme Brasserie des Pyramides aura lieu a Bruxelles le 2 mai prochain A l’ordre du jour : rapport du conseil; approbation des comptes de l’exercice 1905 et fixation du dividends a payer le 15 Mai 1906. Les actionnaires de la Societe Agricole et Industrielle d’Egypte sont convoques en assem- blee generale ordinaire le jeudi 3 Mai, a 4 h. p.m., au siege social au Caire. A l’ondre du jour: rapport du conseil, approbation des comptes et fixation du dividends pour l’exercise 1905, nominations statutaires, etc. Grace a l’heureuse terminaison de la conte- rence d’Algesiras, la reprise que nous avons prevne pour cette date va se produire a bref delai.

div.head: LES PUISSANCES
div.p: DEVANT LA REVOLTS ARABE. *

Tandis que 1'attention de la France et de 1’Europe etait absorbee par la guerre russo- japonaise, puis par les debuts des affaires maro- caines, un drame politique d’un interet tragique et d’une importance mondiale commencait a s'ouvrir dans la partie naturellement la plus riche, mais aussi, depuis de longs siecles, la plus abandonnee et la plus ignoree de l’Empire ottoman, l’Arabie. Longtemps opprime, et en apparence, en- dormi, le peuple arabe se reveille et revendiqne son independance. Or, qni dira, qui osera prevoir la repercus¬sion de cet etonnant mouvement sur la politi¬-que des Etats europeens, tous interesses, et la France la premiere, en sa qualite de grande puissance musulmane, a cette crise redoutable de la domination torque? Probleme pressant, d’une gravite qu’on ne peut exagerer et sur lequel il importe que l’opinion francaise soit renseignee au plus tot. Ce sera le grand bienfait du livre si informe et si sur de M. Eugene Jung que de nous mettre, par un expose lumineux et magistral de l’histoire du pays, de ses ressources economi- ques, de la revolution qui l’agite, de la situa-tion respective des puissances, en l’etat d’abor- der ce snjet. aujourd’hui presque inconnu, et qui sera demain la matiere des polemiques internationales les plus passionnees. *La Crise Mondiale de domain, par M. Eu- gene Jung, aucien Vice-Resident de Franoe en Indo-Chine.— Un volume in 16. avec one carte, broche, 3 fr. 50 (Hachette et Cie. Paris).
